newsitem.title: TURKEY: Turkish shares surge on selective demand.
newsitem.headline: Turkish shares surge on selective demand.

text.p: Turkish shares rose by 1.47 percent on Wednesday amid selective demand and improved market mood, brokers said.
The IMKB-100 .ISEC stood at 64,302.67, up 932.98 points from Tuesday. Gains so far this week have totalled 3.12 percent.
Daily volume rose to 7.8 trillion lira ($90.7 million) from Tuesday's 5.0 trillion ($58.1 million)
"The market can rise to 65,000 tomorrow but profit-taking sales may come after that," said Cenk Akyoldas from Yatirim Finansman.
"I think the buying in state shares came in the afternoon because share prices are cheap and there was nothing to spoil market mood," he added.
Brokers said buying in state-sector shares towards the end of the session had spilled over to the rest of the market, dragging the index higher.

They said there was still no fresh cash entry to the market in the lack of fresh expectations or market-moving news but they said cheaper prices after last week's 4.16 percent drop spurred selective activity. SA ERC
